meta.name: description
meta.content: The Accept-Encoding HTTP request-header specify response content codings that are acceptable to the user-agent.

main.p: The Accept-Encoding header specifies which response content codings are acceptable to the client.
This header is typically used to indicate the user agent supports compressed response messages, such as gzip.

Write an Accept-Encoding header listing which content codings it is capable of decoding, especially compression methods. Check the response Content-Encoding header to determine how to decode the message body, if necessary.

Using the Accept-Encoding header to select a response content coding is not trivial; keep a mapping of supported content-codings to available encoders or encoded representations, and use a library to match the incoming Accept-Encoding to an available encoding. If more than one representation could be selected from, add a Vary header of Vary: Accept-Encoding to indicate to caches that the response might vary based on this header.
For HTTP/Web applications, consider using a transforming HTTP gateway or cache to perform this step, instead of adding this complexity in the application.

dl.dd: Specifies which response content codings are acceptable.

dd.a: RFC 7231: HTTP/1.1 Semantics and Content §5.3.2. Accept-Encoding

main.pre: Accept-Encoding = #( codings [ weight ] ) codings = content-coding / "identity" / "*" weight = OWS ";" OWS "q=" qvalue qvalue = ( "0" [ "." 0*3DIGIT ] ) / ( "1" [ "." 0*3("0") ] )
